large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary (appear, soil).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking: What happens to plants and animals in each season?
Read for understanding and enjoyment, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Describe the life cycles of different plants and animals.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to categorize pictures of nature to tell whether they show a spring or a fall scene.
Guide children to talk about characteristics of spring and of fall.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do during different seasons?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a picture of fall in a book? How can you tell it’s fall?
Can you pretend to be a leaf falling from a tree? What do you look like? How will you move?
How can you sort these foods into different categories?
What fall or spring activity can you draw?
What materials can you use to show a flower growing? How will you make its stem and leaves?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word high? Can you write that letter?
Can you use blocks to make a pumpkin patch? What will your pumpkin patch look like?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder make connections and introduce vocabulary (connection seasons).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder and Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy .
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Make connections between situations.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children talk about different pictures that show people outdoors in different seasons.
Challenge children to act out how they would play in the places and seasons shown.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do during different seasons?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find in a book a picture of the season we’re in now?
Pretend that it is winter and you are very cold. How would you hold your body? Now pretend it is summer and you are very hot. Show how you would hold your body in the heat.
Can you show a counter for each season? How many counters do you have?
Make a picture of your favorite season.
Can you make a leaf out of clay?
Can you stack three Os to draw a snowman? Add eyes and a nose to the top O.
Show what you can build that would help you stay warm in winter.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy: What Are Seasons? by Jane Brocket. Text and photographs copyright © 2015 by Jane Brocket. large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Share the comprehension skill Categorize and introduce vocabulary (shelter, gust).
Begin Story Time by reading Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy and asking the guiding question What is the weather like in each season?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Make connections between situations.
Use information to categorize; Use information to describe.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to categorize pictures of weather to tell whether they show a summer or a winter scene.
Guide children to talk about both winter and summer.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do during different seasons?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the plants in that book different during different seasons?
Pretend to skate on ice. Then, pretend to swim in water.
Compare the size of two kinds of plants. Which is bigger? How do you know?
If you lived in a place that had only one season, which season would you want it to be? Write or draw about it.
How can you make a snow animal out of something else? What materials can you use?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the words hot and happy? Can you draw the letter that stands for that sound?
Can you use blocks to build a shelter from the rain?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy: What Are Seasons? by Jane Brocket. Text and photographs copyright © 2015 by Jane Brocket. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Millbrook Press, a division of Lerner Publishing Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Changing Seasons

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Science: Life Science; Earth and Space Science

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about the seasons, sing a song about seasons, and introduce vocabulary (seasons, plant).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts The Changing Seasons and Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question: What do we do during different seasons?
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and action.
Make connections between situations.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Describe life cycles of different plants and animals.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children as they put in order four picture cards that show apple trees during the four seasons.
Talk with children about what happens to the trees during the different seasons.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do during different seasons?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find in a book a plant that gets bigger in summer than it was in spring?
Show what you would do with a basket of apples in fall.
Can you group plants in order from smallest to biggest?
Which season has the most fun things to do? Can you write about that season?
Can you use clay to make a sled like the one on the poster?
Can you show me what letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of bat? How about hat? What other sounds are in these words? Say all the sounds slowly.
Can you build an apple tree in fall? How many apples will it have? How will you show the apples?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy: What Are Seasons? by Jane Brocket. Text and photographs copyright © 2015 by Jane Brocket. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Millbrook Press, a division of Lerner Publishing Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Sunny

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out and describe different seasonal activities and to introduce vocabulary (bare, carve).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What do you do in different weather?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Make connections between situations.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Blend phonemes into one-syllable words.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What do we do during different seasons?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing in a Sleeved Booklet to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do during different seasons?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What would you put in your own book about the seasons?
Can you pretend to be a dog enjoying the snow in winter?
Can you sort objects you find to go with different seasons (example: autumn leaf with fall)?
Can you write a story about an animal born in spring and how it changes through the seasons?
Can you make an object that you connect with the season we are in now?
What sound does a gust of wind make? What letters would you use to make that sound?
How will you create a shelter for a plant so that it survives cold and windy weather?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy: What Are Seasons? by Jane Brocket. Text and photographs copyright © 2015 by Jane Brocket. tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Make connections between situations.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Make connections between situations.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Sort objects that are the same and different into groups and use language to describe how the groups are similar and different.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than they use.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Make connections between situations.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than they use.
Increase listening vocabulary and begins to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Make connections between situations.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Recognize and blend spoken phonemes into one-syllable words with pictorial support.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
